article.title: The Hash Interface
article.para: The drew hash interface is designed to be simple and easy to use. The main object is the drew_hash_t.

As with other interfaces, the ctx holds the actual context of the underlying implementation; this could be in C or C++. It is opaque to users of libdrew. The functbl field is a list of entry points to the hash implementation in question. All hash implementations must implement all entry points. It is guaranteed that two hash contexts that have the same functbl pointer share an implementation of the same algorithm. However, it is possible that an implementation may have several valid values for the functbl argument. The priv variable is not used and is reserved for the user application.

Before a hash context can be used, the functbl argument must be initialized to a valid value obtained from drew_loader_get_functbl. Calling an entry point function may result in the functbl value being changed. Usually, this is to enable the use of a more efficient or optimized implementation when possible. However, it is guaranteed that the value obtained from the loader will function correctly, even if not optimally.

Each of the elements of a drew_hash_functbl_t is a pointer to function returning int. A successful call to one of these functions will generally return 0. Sometimes, a successful call may return some data useful to the caller; this data will be a positive integer. An unsuccessful call will return a negative integer representing an error. If the absolute value of that error value is less than 65536, it is a system error code and the normal errno routines should be used to manipulate it. Otherwise, it is a libdrew error code as specified in drew/plugin.h.

Certain function calls are only permitted in a certain order. For ease of understanding, the permissible order is modeled using a state machine. A hash context, once it has had its functbl value initialized, is in the UNINITIALIZED state. It is not required that an implementation return an error when functions are called in an incorrect order.
This function provides information about the algorithm in question. The type of information depends on the op parameter.

To determine the ABI version of the plugin, which affects the layout of the function table, which entry points are available, and the arguments and return values of those entry points, use the DREW_HASH_VERSION operation with NULL as p; the ABI version will be returned. It is guaranteed that regardless of the ABI, this interface will be present as the first function pointer in the table and that it will be present with this prototype.

The following table indicates the valid values for op and p, as well as the expected return value. If p is specified as taking either NULL or a hash context, NULL is acceptable unless the function returns -DREW_ERR_MORE_INFO, in which case a hash context is required. This allows the implementation to support a wide variety of values, such as with the digest size of SHA-512/t.

article.para: To call init, the hash context must be in the UNINITIALIZED state. Upon successful completion, the hash context will be in the ALIGNED state. The function initializes the hash context ctx. If the flags parameter contains the bit DREW_HASH_FIXED, then the ctx field of the ctx parameter is presumed to point to a suitably-aligned allocation of memory of at least the value returned by a call to the info function with op set to DREW_HASH_INTSIZE. Otherwise, memory will be allocated for the implementation context.

It is suggested that a valid loader context be passed as ldr, so that an implementation may create its own libdrew contexts if it needs them internally. This is optional, however; if no loader context is available, simply pass NULL. If it is non-NULL, param should be a linked list of parameters.

The clone may be called at any time. It copies the context specified in ctx (in any state other than UNINITIALIZED) to a new context in newctx that is currently in the UNINITIALIZED state. After a successful call, the newctx will acquire a separate but otherwise identical state from ctx. The flags parameter has the same meaning as for init.

The reset function may be called in any state other than UNINITIALIZED; after a successful call, the hash context will be in the ALIGNED state. The result is as if the fini function were called, followed by a call to the init function with the same parameters as used in the original call.

The fini takes a context and frees any resources used by it. The context must be in a state other than UNINITIALIZED when fini is called; upon successful completion, the context will be in the UNINITIALIZED state. The functbl field of the context is not modified. If flags contains the bit DREW_HASH_FIXED, the ctx field of the context is unmodified; otherwise, it is set to NULL.

This function adds data to the hash. It may be called in the ALIGNED or UNALIGNED and upon successful completion leaves the hash context in the UNALIGNED state. The underlying implementation may choose to buffer the data if needed, but if so, it will copy the data to internal storage.

This function adds data to the hash. It may be called only in the ALIGNED state; successful completion does not change the state. For efficiency reasons, the data must be 16-byte aligned. The length of the data as given by len must be a multiple of 16 and also a multiple of the block size, which can be determined using the DREW_HASH_BLKSIZE operation on the info function. Except for potential performance benefits and the corresponding restrictions, updatefast is functionally equivalent to update.

This function pads the data as required by the hash function. In general, this function is never needed; the final function will automatically pad the data correctly unless specifically instructed otherwise. Nevertheless, it is provided for compatibility reasons. Double-padding will produce incorrect results.
This function can be called in the ALIGNED or UNALIGNED state and upon successful completion, leaves the hash context in the PADDED state.

This function computes the final digest and stores it in the buffer buf. The buffer must be of at least the size returned by the DREW_HASH_SIZE operation of the info function. If the bit DREW_HASH_NO_PAD is set in flags, then no padding is performed and the state must be PADDED; otherwise, the appropriate padding is performed and the state must be ALIGNED or UNALIGNED. Upon successful completion, the state will be FINISHED.
